template.template: Template OS Windows by Zabbix agent active
template.name: Template OS Windows by Zabbix agent active
template.description:
Name: Template OS Windows by Zabbix agent active
Description: Aggregate templates for monitoring Windows components
Homepage: https://github.com/itmicus/zabbix
Issues: https://github.com/itmicus/zabbix/issues
Author: itmicus.ru
Version: 1.0
Changelog: The format is based on [Keep a Changelog](https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.0.0/)
## [1.0.0] - 2019-09-03 ### Added - Separation of operating system monitoring into major components: cpu, memory, disk, network - Templates follow Zabbix template guidelines (https://www.zabbix.com/documentation/4.4/manual/appendix/templates/template_guidelines) - All triggers redesigned, only key triggers left that show real problems - All macros and regular expressions moved to templates
### Changed
For explanation:

template.name: Template OS Windows CPU by Zabbix agent active
Template OS Windows Disk by Zabbix agent active
Template OS Windows Inventory by Zabbix agent active
Template OS Windows Memory by Zabbix agent active
Template OS Windows Network by Zabbix agent active

template.template: Template OS Windows CPU by Zabbix agent active
template.name: Template OS Windows CPU by Zabbix agent active
template.description:
Name: Template OS Windows CPU by Zabbix agent active
Description:Template for monitoring Windows CPU
Homepage: https://github.com/itmicus/zabbix
Issues: https://github.com/itmicus/zabbix/issues
Author: itmicus.ru
Version: 1.0
Changelog: The format is based on [Keep a Changelog](https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.0.0/)
## [1.0.0] - 2019-09-03 ### Added - Templates follow Zabbix template guidelines (https://www.zabbix.com/documentation/4.4/manual/appendix/templates/template_guidelines)
For explanation:
http://toncigrgin.blogspot.com/2015/11/windows-perf-counters-blog5.html
https://wutils.com/wmi/root/cimv2/
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/test/wpt/cpu-analysis

item.name: CPU: Load (1 min average per core)
item.description: The processor load is calculated as system CPU load divided by number of CPU cores.

item.name: CPU: Load (5 min average per core)
item.description: The processor load is calculated as system CPU load divided by number of CPU cores.

item.name: CPU: Load (15 min average per core)
item.description: The processor load is calculated as system CPU load divided by number of CPU cores.

item.name: CPU: Interrupt Time, %
item.description:
Processor\% Interrupt Time
This measures the time the processor spends receiving and servicing hardware interruptions during specific sample intervals. This counter indicates a possible hardware issue if the value is greater than 15 percent.

item.name: CPU: Privileged time, %
item.description:
Processor\% Privileged Time
This is the percentage of elapsed time that the process threads spent executing code in privileged mode. When a Windows system service in called, the service will often run in privileged mode to gain access to system-private data. Such data is protected from access by threads executing in user mode. Calls to the system can be explicit or implicit, such as page faults or interrupts. Unlike some early operating systems, Windows uses process boundaries for subsystem protection in addition to the traditional protection of user and privileged modes. Some work done by Windows on behalf of the application might appear in other subsystem processes in addition to the privileged time in the process.
The Processor performance object consists of counters that measure aspects of processor activity The processor is the part of the computer that performs arithmetic and logical computations, initiates operations on peripherals, and runs the threads of processes. A computer can have multiple processors. The processor object represents each processor as an instance of the object.

item.name: CPU: Load, %
item.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select PercentProcessorTime from Win32_PerfformattedData_PerfOS_Processor where Name='_Total']
item.description: \Processor Information(_Total)\% Processor Time

item.name: CPU: User time, %
item.description:
Processor\% User Time
This measures the percentage of elapsed time the processor spends in user mode. If this value is high, the server is busy with the application. One possible solution here is to optimize the application that is using up the processor resources.

item.name: CPU: Queue Length
item.description:
System\Processor Queue Length
This indicates the number of threads in the processor queue. The server doesn't have enough processor power if the value is more than two times the number of CPUs for an extended period of time.

template.template: Template OS Windows Disk by Zabbix agent active
template.name: Template OS Windows Disk by Zabbix agent active
template.description:

Description: Template for monitoring Windows Disk

## [1.0.0] - 2019-09-03 ### Added - Templates follow Zabbix template guidelines (https://www.zabbix.com/documentation/4.4/manual/appendix/templates/template_guidelines)

discovery_rule.name: Mounted filesystem discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovery of file systems of different types as defined in global regular expression "File systems for discovery".

item_prototype.name: {#FSNAME}: Used disk space, 12h linear forecast shifted

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template OS Windows Disk by Zabbix agent active:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},free].last(0)}<{$DISK.FILESYSTEM.SPACE.LIMIT:"{#FSNAME}"}
trigger_prototype.name: {#FSNAME}: Free disk space is less (Last: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}, Limit {$DISK.FILESYSTEM.SPACE.LIMIT})

item.host: Template OS Windows Disk by Zabbix agent active
Template OS Windows Disk by Zabbix agent active
Template OS Windows Disk by Zabbix agent active

template.name: Template OS Windows Disk Performance by Zabbix agent active

template.template: Template OS Windows Disk Performance by Zabbix agent active
template.name: Template OS Windows Disk Performance by Zabbix agent active
template.description:
Name: Template OS Windows Disk Performance by Zabbix agent active
Description:Template for monitoring Windows Disk Performance
Homepage: https://github.com/itmicus/zabbix
Issues: https://github.com/itmicus/zabbix/issues
Author: itmicus.ru
Version: 1.0
Changelog: The format is based on [Keep a Changelog](https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.0.0/)
## [1.0.0] - 2019-09-03 ### Added - Templates follow Zabbix template guidelines (https://www.zabbix.com/documentation/4.4/manual/appendix/templates/template_guidelines)

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template OS Windows Disk Performance by Zabbix agent active:wmi.get[root\cimv2,select AvgDisksecPerRead from Win32_PerfFormattedData_PerfDisk_PhysicalDisk where Name='{#DEVICENAME}'].avg(15m)}>{$DISK.READ.AVG}
trigger_prototype.name: {#DEVICENAME}: Avg. Disk sec/Read (over {$DISK.READ.AVG} ms for 15m)

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template OS Windows Disk Performance by Zabbix agent active:wmi.get[root\cimv2,select AvgDisksecPerWrite from Win32_PerfFormattedData_PerfDisk_PhysicalDisk where Name='{#DEVICENAME}'].avg(15m)}>{$DISK.WRITE.AVG}
trigger_prototype.name: {#DEVICENAME}: Avg. Disk sec/Write (over {$DISK.WRITE.AVG} ms for 15m)

template.template: Template OS Windows Memory by Zabbix agent active
template.name: Template OS Windows Memory by Zabbix agent active
template.description:
Name: Template OS Windows Memory by Zabbix agent active
Description: Template for monitoring Windows Memory
Homepage: https://github.com/itmicus/zabbix
Issues: https://github.com/itmicus/zabbix/issues
Author: itmicus.ru
Version: 1.0
Changelog: The format is based on [Keep a Changelog](https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.0.0/)
## [1.0.0] - 2019-09-03 ### Added - Separation of operating system monitoring into major components: cpu, memory, disk, network - Templates follow Zabbix template guidelines (https://www.zabbix.com/documentation/4.4/manual/appendix/templates/template_guidelines) - All triggers redesigned, only key triggers left that show real problems - All macros and regular expressions moved to templates
### Changed
For explanation:
http://toncigrgin.blogspot.com/2015/11/windows-perf-counters-blog5.html
https://wutils.com/wmi/root/cimv2/
http://perfbasics.blogspot.com/2017/03/windows-monitoring.html

item.name: Memory: Available
item.description: Performance counter measures the amount of physical memory (RAM), in megabytes, that is immediately available for allocation either to a process or for system use. It is the sum of the Zero, Free, and Standby page lists discussed earlier. When the Available MBytes counter is low, it is a primary indicator of a low RAM condition. This is when aggressive working set trims will occur which may or may not result in a hard page fault where the pages on the Modified list are written to disk. The \Memory\Pages/sec counter measures hard page faults, but it does not distinguish between hard page faults that result from normal file reads or writes and page file reads or writes. Therefore, use Pages/sec together with the Available MBytes counter, and do not use Pages/sec by itself.

item.name: Memory: Cache bytes
item.description:
\Memory\Cache Bytes
Cache Bytes is the sum of the Memory\\System Cache Resident Bytes, Memory\\System Driver Resident Bytes, Memory\\System Code Resident Bytes, and Memory\\Pool Paged Resident Bytes counters. This counter displays the last observed value only; it is not an average.
The Memory performance object consists of counters that describe the behavior of physical and virtual memory on the computer. Physical memory is the amount of random access memory on the computer. Virtual memory consists of the space in physical memory and on disk. Many of the memory counters monitor paging, which is the movement of pages of code and data between disk and physical memory. Excessive paging, a symptom of a memory shortage, can cause delays which interfere with all system processes.

item.name: Memory: Commit limit
item.description: Commit Limit is the amount of virtual memory that can be committed without having to extend the paging file(s). It is measured in bytes. Committed memory is the physical memory which has space reserved on the disk paging files. There can be one paging file on each logical drive). If the paging file(s) are be expanded, this limit increases accordingly. This counter displays the last observed value only; it is not an average.

item.name: Memory: Committed
item.description:
\Memory\% Committed Bytes
The system commit charge is the total amount of committed memory that is in use by all processes and by the kernel. This memory might have been guaranteed or written to by a process or by the kernel.
Memory Available Megabytes in Use This measures the ratio of Committed Bytes to the Commit Limit—in other words, the amount of virtual memory in use. This indicates insufficient memory if the number is greater than 80 percent. The obvious solution for this is to add more memory.

item.name: Memory: Free system page table entries
item.description:
Memory\Free System Page Table Entries
This indicates the number of page table entries not currently in use by the system. If the number is less than 5,000, there may well be a memory leak.

item.name: Memory: Pages faults per/sec
item.description: Page Faults/sec is the average number of pages faulted per second. It is measured in number of pages faulted per second because only one page is faulted in each fault operation, hence this is also equal to the number of page fault operations. This counter includes both hard faults (those that require disk access) and soft faults (where the faulted page is found elsewhere in physical memory.) Most processors can handle large numbers of soft faults without significant consequence. However, hard faults, which require disk access, can cause significant delays.

item.name: Memory: Pages per/sec
item.description:
Memory\Pages per Second
This measures the rate at which pages are read from or written to disk to resolve hard page faults. If the value is greater than 1,000, as a result of excessive paging, there may be a memory leak.

item.name: Memory: Committed in use, %
item.description:
\Memory\% Committed Bytes
The \Memory\% Committed Bytes In Use counter calculates the ratio of committed bytes (system commit charge) to the system commit limit, and the system can perform poorly when the system commit limit is reached. Therefore, when % Committed Bytes In Use is greater than 80%, use the \Process(*)\Private Bytes counter to identify the processes that are consuming the most committed memory. The Debug Diagnostic Tool (DebugDiag) is designed to assist in troubleshooting issues such as hangs, slow performance, memory leaks or fragmentation, and crashes in any user-mode process. The tool includes additional debugging scripts focused on Internet Information Services (IIS) applications, web data access components, COM+ and related Microsoft technologies.

item.name: Memory: Page file usage, %
item.description:
The peak usage of the Page File instance in percent.
The Paging File performance object consists of counters that monitor the paging file(s) on the computer. The paging file is a reserved space on disk that backs up committed physical memory on the computer.

item.name: Memory: Pool non-paged
item.description:
Memory\Pool Non-Paged Bytes
This measures the size, in bytes, of the non-paged pool. This is an area of system memory for objects that cannot be written to disk but instead must remain in physical memory as long as they are allocated. There is a possible memory leak if the value is greater than 175MB (or 100MB with the /3GB switch). A typical Event ID 2019 is recorded in the system event log.

item.name: Memory: Pool paged
item.description:
Memory\Pool Paged Bytes
This measures the size, in bytes, of the paged pool. This is an area of system memory used for objects that can be written to disk when they are not being used. There may be a memory leak if this value is greater than 250MB (or 170MB with the /3GB switch). A typical Event ID 2020 is recorded in the system event log.

template.template: Template OS Windows Network by Zabbix agent active
template.name: Template OS Windows Network by Zabbix agent active
template.description:
Name: Template OS Windows Network by Zabbix agent active
Description: Template for monitoring Windows Network
Homepage: https://github.com/itmicus/zabbix
Issues: https://github.com/itmicus/zabbix/issues
Author: itmicus.ru
Version: 1.0
Changelog: The format is based on [Keep a Changelog](https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.0.0/)
## [1.0.0] - 2019-09-03 ### Added - Separation of operating system monitoring into major components: cpu, memory, disk, network - Templates follow Zabbix template guidelines (https://www.zabbix.com/documentation/4.4/manual/appendix/templates/template_guidelines) - All triggers redesigned, only key triggers left that show real problems - All macros and regular expressions moved to templates
### Changed
For explanation:
http://toncigrgin.blogspot.com/2015/11/windows-perf-counters-blog5.html
https://wutils.com/wmi/root/cimv2/

discovery_rule.name: Network interface discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovery of network interfaces as defined in global regular expression "Network interfaces for discovery".

item_prototype.name: {#IFNAME}: Network utilization, %
item_prototype.params: ( (last("wmi.get[root\cimv2,select BytesTotalPersec from Win32_PerfFormattedData_Tcpip_NetworkInterface where Name='{#IFNAME}']") *8) / last("wmi.get[root\cimv2,select CurrentBandwidth from Win32_PerfFormattedData_Tcpip_NetworkInterface where Name='{#IFNAME}']"))*100

item_prototype.name: {#IFNAME}: Network address
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select MACAddress from win32_networkadapter where InterfaceIndex='{#IFINDEX}']

item_prototype.name: {#IFNAME}: Network carrier
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select NetConnectionStatus from win32_networkadapter where InterfaceIndex='{#IFINDEX}']

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template OS Windows Network by Zabbix agent active:wmi.get[root\cimv2,select NetConnectionStatus from win32_networkadapter where InterfaceIndex='{#IFINDEX}'].diff(0)}>0
trigger_prototype.name: {#IFNAME}: Changed network carrier

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template OS Windows Network by Zabbix agent active:wmi.get[root\cimv2,select CurrentBandwidth from Win32_PerfFormattedData_Tcpip_NetworkInterface where Name='{#IFNAME}'].diff(0)}>0
trigger_prototype.name: {#IFNAME}: Changed network speed

item.host: Template OS Windows Network by Zabbix agent active
Template OS Windows Network by Zabbix agent active

macro.value: (WAN Miniport.*|veth.*|Teredo Tunneling Pseudo-Interface|Microsoft (ISATAP|Wi-Fi Direct Virtual|Kernel Debug Network) Adapter.*|(In)?[Ll]oop[Bb]ack[0-9._]*|Software Loopback Interface|.*Virtual Switch Extension Adapter)

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows CPU by Zabbix agent active:wmi.get[root\cimv2,SELECT PercentInterruptTime FROM Win32_PerfFormattedData_PerfOS_Processor].avg(30m)}>{$CPU.INTERRUPTTIME.PCT}
trigger.recovery_expression: {Template OS Windows CPU by Zabbix agent active:wmi.get[root\cimv2,SELECT PercentInterruptTime FROM Win32_PerfFormattedData_PerfOS_Processor].avg(30m)}<{$CPU.INTERRUPTTIME.PCT}
trigger.name: CPU: Interrupt time is too high (over {$CPU.INTERRUPTTIME.PCT}% for 30m)

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows CPU by Zabbix agent active:wmi.get[root\cimv2,select PercentProcessorTime from Win32_PerfformattedData_PerfOS_Processor where Name='_Total'].avg(30m)}>{$CPU.LOAD.MAX.PCT}
trigger.name: CPU: Load is too high (over {$CPU.LOAD.MAX.PCT}% for 30m)
trigger.description: If % Processor Time is 80% or higher, the first path to explore is determining if there is a legitimate need to increase CPU capacity of your Lync Servers. Windows Server 2008 introduced new Power Management settings (which are on by default) to help reduce carbon footprint produced from Servers by consuming less electricity by parking CPU cores that are lightly utilized by moving those tasks to other cores. What this means is that high Processor Time values no longer automatically mean the physical CPUs are approaching their hardware limits

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Inventory by Zabbix agent active:system.uname.diff(0)}>0
trigger.name: OS: Host information was changed

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Inventory by Zabbix agent active:system.hostname.diff(0)}>0
trigger.name: OS: Hostname was changed

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Inventory by Zabbix agent active:system.localtime[utc].fuzzytime({$OS.FUZZY.TIME.MAX})}=0
trigger.name: OS: It is necessary to adjust the local time (over {$OS.FUZZY.TIME.MAX} s)

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Inventory by Zabbix agent active:system.uptime.change(0)}<0
trigger.name: OS: Just been restarted

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Inventory by Zabbix agent active:custom.os.updates.latestupdatesinstalled.last()}>{$OS.UPDATES.LATEST.INFO}
trigger.name: OS: Latest windows updates installed (over {$OS.UPDATES.LATEST.INFO} days ago)

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Inventory by Zabbix agent active:custom.os.updates.latestupdatesinstalled.last()}>{$OS.UPDATES.LATEST.WARN}
trigger.name: OS: Latest windows updates installed (over {$OS.UPDATES.LATEST.WARN} days ago)

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Inventory by Zabbix agent active:custom.os.pendingreboot.last()}=1
trigger.recovery_expression: {Template OS Windows Inventory by Zabbix agent active:custom.os.pendingreboot.last()}=0
trigger.name: OS: Pending reboot

trigger.expression: {Template OS Windows Inventory by Zabbix agent active:custom.os.powershell.version.last()}<{$OS.POWERSHELL.VER.MIN}
trigger.name: OS: PowerShell minimal requires version (limit {$OS.POWERSHELL.VER.MIN})
trigger.description: Please update PowerShell to 3 or higher, otherwise part of the metrics will not work
